summary: The document provides a detailed account of Santiago Sanchez de la Torre's involvement with the Movimiento Revolucionario del Pueblo (MRR) in opposition to the Castro regime in Cuba during the early 1960s. It outlines his activities, including assisting a KUBARK infiltration team, providing a safehouse, and his role in reorganizing the MRR in Las Villas Province after the failure of Playa Giron. The report also covers his and his wife's arrests, their life 'in black', escape from prison, and eventual asylum process, culminating in their move to Mexico City. Additionally, it touches on internal conflicts within the MRR, suspicions of betrayal, and failed operations, alongside mentions of other individuals involved in the movement and Cuban power plants.
key_findings: Santiago Sanchez de la Torre was actively involved in the MRR's efforts against the Castro regime, including supporting a KUBARK infiltration team and offering a safehouse for operations.
Following the Playa Giron failure, Sanchez contributed to the MRR's reorganization in Las Villas Province, focusing on civil coordination.
Sanchez and his wife faced arrest in July 1961, leading to a period of hiding until seeking asylum in September 1962.
The document highlights internal MRR conflicts, including betrayal suspicions and an unsuccessful assassination attempt.
Sanchez's wife escaped prison in April 1962, with the couple later seeking asylum at the Uruguayan Embassy before relocating to Mexico City in June 1963.
Attachments include lists of individuals working in Cuban power plants and a debriefing on Angel Bencomo, implicated in the MRR's 'roll-up'.
